item.title: Oil Dips as Traders Take Stock of US Tariffs and OPEC+ Shift
item.description: Oil slipped for the third time in four days as investors focused on the fallout from a wave of US trade levies and a decision by OPEC+ to restore more of the group’s idled capacity.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Lua

item.title: Stocks Edge Up as Trump Hints at More Trade Talks: Markets Wrap
item.description: Most Asian indexes rose as President Donald Trump left the door open for additional trade talks, providing a reprieve to markets after imposing new tariff rates on several countries.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

item.title: Your Tariffs Are in the Mail, Sealed With a Diss
item.description: There’s still a lot of drama left for trading partners who haven’t received letters yet.
item.dc:creator: John Authers

media:content.media:description: Karoline Leavitt, White House press secretary, holds a trade letter sent by the White House to South Korea during a news conference in the James S. Brady Press Briefing Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, July 7, 2025. President Donald Trump unveiled the first in a wave of promised letters that threaten to impose higher tariffs rates on key trading partners, including levies of 25% on goods from Japan and South Korea beginning Aug. 1. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Jane Street’s Lucrative India Trade Highlights Key Market Quirk
item.description: The trading strategy that helped Jane Street Group earn billions of dollars in India likely wouldn’t have worked nearly as well in other markets.
item.dc:creator: Cecile Vannucci, Chiranjivi Chakraborty

item.title: Huayou Cobalt Shares Jump on Record Profit Boosted by Indonesia
item.description: China’s Zhejiang Huayou Cobalt Co. Ltd’s share prices surged to a near four-month high, after the company projected record half-year earnings, driven by the ramp-up of its nickel projects in Indonesia and a boost from rising cobalt prices.
item.dc:creator: Annie Lee

item.title: Australian Bonds Draw Largest Japanese Inflows in Two Years
item.description: Australian bonds attracted the largest inflow from Japanese investors in more than two years as lower currency hedging costs boosted the attractiveness of the Antipodean bonds.
item.dc:creator: Masaki Kondo

item.title: Indian Gift City Exchange Set for First Foreign-Currency Listing
item.description: India’s NSE International Exchange is aiming to attract its first equity listing in a foreign currency this quarter, a milestone it says will demonstrate a new fundraising avenue for firms.
item.dc:creator: Subhadip Sircar, Saikat Das

item.title: Shenzhen Bourse Nudges China Firms to Speed Up IPO Applications
item.description: China’s Shenzhen Stock Exchange has urged brokers to speed up applications for companies to list on the ChiNext board as officials seek to boost private enterprise and reignite the economy under threat from rising tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu

item.title: Tariffs Becoming Broader Tool, HSBC's Neumann Says
item.description: HSBC's Frederic Neumann says the financial markets "have not reacted" to President Trump "basically extending" the trade talks deadline. He also tells Bloomberg Television that "tariffs are becoming a broader tool" for other purposes beyond adjusting trade deficits. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: The Asia Trade 8/7/25
item.description: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Singapore and Sydney with Avril Hong and Haidi Stroud-Watts, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nissan CDS Jumps to 16-Year High on $4 Billion Foreign Bond Plan
item.description: Nissan Motor Co.’s credit-default swaps widened to the highest level since 2009 after the automaker began preparing a $4 billion foreign-currency bond sale, stoking concerns about rising interest expenses.
item.dc:creator: Takahiko Hyuga

item.title: Japan, Korea Keep Pushing for Lower US Tariffs as Deadline Moves
item.description: Japan and South Korea said they’ll keep pushing for a better deal for their exports to the US after President Donald Trump shifted his tariff deadline to Aug. 1 and tweaked the rates he’s set for many economies.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Soo-Hyang Choi

item.title: Indian Rupee Underperforms Most Emerging Asian Currencies on Tariff Worries
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Alex Gabriel Simon

item.title: Trump Issues New Tariff Rates, Says US Still Open to Talks
item.description: President Donald Trump unveiled the first in a wave of promised letters that threaten to impose higher tariff rates on key trading partners. But he also suggested that he was still open to additional negotiations and pushed off increased duties until at least August 1. Bloomberg's Stephen Engle reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Australian Asset Managers Platinum and L1 Capital to Merge
item.description: Australian investment firms Platinum Asset Management Ltd. and L1 Capital have agreed to a merger, adding to a flurry of recent deal activity involving money managers in the country.
item.dc:creator: Chris Bourke

item.title: Japanese Stocks Swing on Trump Tariffs, South Korea Holds Gains
item.description: Japanese stocks fluctuated while South Korean equities held on to gains on cautious hopes that the countries can reach trade deals ahead of US President Donald Trump’s newly-extended tariff deadline.
item.dc:creator: Alice French, Sangmi Cha

item.title: Stonepeak Is Said in Talks to Invest in Warburg-Backed Princeton
item.description: Stonepeak Partners is in talks to invest in data center operator Princeton Digital Group, people familiar with the matter said, as the US infrastructure investor seeks to build up its presence in Asia Pacific.
item.dc:creator: Manuel Baigorri, Vinicy Chan, Pei Li

item.title: China Shuns Costly LNG Imports Even as Summer Power Demand Rises
item.description: Sweltering temperatures are pushing up appetite for electricity in China — just not yet enough to revive the country’s spot purchases of costly liquefied natural gas.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Stapczynski, Kathy Chen

item.title: Samsung’s Profit Halves in Deepening Chip Business Crisis
item.description: Samsung Electronics Co.’s profit fell for the first time since 2023, reflecting the deepening market share losses clouding the memory chipmaker’s prospects in the AI era.
item.dc:creator: Yoolim Lee

media:content.media:description: The Samsung Electronics headquarters in Suwon, South Korea.

item.title: Iron Ore Seesaws as Traders Assess Trump’s Tariff Announcements
item.description: Iron ore fluctuated as US President Donald Trump signaled he was open to more negotiations after he unveiled his first wave of letters threatening to impose higher tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Gemmell

item.title: Emerging Market Currencies Rise as Focus Shifts to Negotiations
item.description: Emerging market currencies recovered some of their losses after US President Donald Trump signaled he is open to negotiations shortly after setting tariff rates for more than a dozen countries.
item.dc:creator: Jaehyun Eom, Matthew Burgess

item.title: Trex CEO on the American Consumer, Tariffs and the Outlook
item.description: Bryan Fairbanks, President and CEO of non-wood decking manufacturer Trex, examines the health of the US consumer, the competitive landscape within his industry, and the uncertainty resulting from President Donald Trump's trade and tariff policy. Bryan speaks with Tim Stenovec and Emily Graffeo on Bloomberg Businessweek Daily. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Steadies as Trump’s Tariff Demands Offset Stronger Dollar
item.description: Gold steadied after reversing losses in the previous session when President Donald Trump began informing a suite of nations of their latest tariff rates, with concerns about a growing US-led trade war bolstering haven demand.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross

item.title: Equities Fall Amid Trump's Tariff Salvo | The Close 7/7/2025
item.description: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are Winnie Cisar Creditsights, Bill Dudley New York Federal Reserve Former President, Rob Owens Piper Sandler, Michelle Meyer Mastercard, Mo Haghbin ProShares, Paul Christopher Wells Fargo Investment Institute, Alan Gerard Balanced Weather, Randy Schwimmer Churchill Asset MGMT Vice Chairman, and Gautam Mukunda, Author “Indispensable: When Leaders Really Matter” and Picking Presidents” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: SoftBank-Backed Ola in Crisis Mode A Year After Blockbuster IPO in India
item.description: Three years ago, when Ola Electric Mobility Ltd.’s scooters were in high demand as an affordable new offering for India’s vast two-wheeler market, co-founder and billionaire Bhavish Aggarwal was spending weeks away in the UK.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Sachdev

item.title: Fund Managers Bet on Bank, Consumer Stocks After India Rate Cuts
item.description: Money managers are betting Indian banking and consumption stocks have further to run this year, benefiting from the central bank’s aggressive policy rate cuts to lift economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Abhishek Vishnoi

item.title: Strategists See Weaker Asian Currencies on Latest Tariff Demands
item.description: Investors will be closely monitoring Asian markets on Tuesday after US President Donald Trump unveiled a wave of promised letters that threaten to impose higher tariffs rates on key trading partners. The levies included tariffs of 25% on goods from Japan and South Korea beginning Aug. 1.
item.dc:creator: Jaehyun Eom, Ruth Carson

media:content.media:description: Bundles of 10,000 won and 10,000 won banknotes arranged at the Shinhan Bank headquarters, a unit of Shinhan Financial Group Co., in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, April 18, 2024. The South Korean won slumps after Federal Reserve officials’ hawkish remarks spurred a rally in the dollar overnight. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Venezuela Bondholders Seek to Block Gold Reserve’s Bid for Citgo
item.description: Holders of some defaulted Venezuelan bonds are seeking to block a bid to purchase Citgo Petroleum Corp.’s parent company, as they claim the transaction would strip them of their rights for payment.
item.dc:creator: Nicolle Yapur

item.title: Restructuring Pressure Rises in Italy and Nordics, BCG Says
item.description: The number of firms under pressure to overhaul or restructure their businesses has risen sharply in Italy and the Nordics, putting both large companies and their supplier networks at risk, according to a report by Boston Consulting Group.
item.dc:creator: Rose Henderson

item.title: Why CEOs Should Stop 'Outsourcing' Politics
item.description: Bloomberg Opinion's Gautam Mukunda explains why CEOs should stop "outsourcing" politics. Mukunda's opinions are his own. (Source: Bloomberg)
